title: Energy conservation - sphere and particle at X Y

content.question: A small charged particle with charge <math alttext="lowercase q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>q</mi></math> is initially a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> from the center of a stationary sphere that has a charge <math alttext="uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> uniformly distributed throughout its volume, as shown in the figure. The small particle is released from rest and moves away from the stationary sphere, passing through locations <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, which are distances <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></math> and <math alttext="3 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi></math>, respectively, from the stationary sphere’s center. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction K sub X over K sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></mfrac></math> of the particle’s kinetic energies at locations <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>? Assume distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> is much larger than the radius of the sphere.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
